html:
3.19.18  6:26 pm   3.18.18  7:08 pm What does an art theif do with a stolen painting?

     How do you sell a famous painting that's been stolen, without it being obvious that you stole the painting?

      Even if you find an art collector who doesn't care that it's a stolen paining, the collector still can't really put up a famous stolen work of art on display in their home. When the mona lisa was famously missing, it would've looked awfully suspicious if some random person just happened to have it hanging up in their living room or something.


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201803181908

3.18.18  7:08 pm   What's the deal with the mona lisa? I mean, it's a cool painting and it looks nice.. but why do people think it's so mysterious and enigmatic? Like, it's just a portrait of some lady. What's all the hubbub about? 

     the mona lisa didn't really enter pop culture until it was stolen from paris in 1911. it might have gained a sense of mystery because everyone was wondering where the heck it was for 2 years

3.17.18  2:41 am   does the delta symbol (Δ) mean maj7 or just major?

     usually just major, but i think there is some confusion about this. a wise person once told me not to use that symbol because on a dimly lit stand it can look like a diminished symbol (circle). so to avoid confusion i think it's best to always write ma, or maj

One thing I've learned that is really important is that it's how the voice matches with the melody and words... like getting the most out of the style of your voice. Good example I can think of is donald fagen. I can't imagine him belting out freddie mercury tunes or something, but I think he's a great singer because his voice is perfect for his melodies/words. I guess I just need to find my 'character' in my voice?

html:
3.15.18  3:06 am   3.14.18  9:02 pm awfully theoretical there, bill


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201803142102

3.14.18  9:02 pm   How come almost everyone would say that a song is in the key of C# instead of the key of Db,

     if it's major it is usually called Db, because that's less degrees in the key signature. but in a loud room, it might be better to verbally say "C#" because if you say Db they might think you said Bb

     but the key of Eb as opposed to the key of D# seems to be the norm,

     right, that's because D# major spelled out properly with letters would have to be D#, E# Fx(double sharp), G#, A#, B#, and Cx(double sharp)

      or F# instead of Gb etc?

     F# and Gb are equivalent choices because they each have 6 degrees in the key signature, but it may be more often called F# for two reasons. one is kind of like the C#/Db case where F# is more verbally clear in a crowded room, but also it is more common for keys to borrow flatter notes than sharper ones. which creates no problems at all in F# where as in Gb it immediately creates double flats. actually i can think of a 3rd reason. F# as a note would be much more common than Gb because F# is the first note to go, in sharp keys. where as in flat keys Gb is is the 5th note to go. so people are already more accustomed to verbally hearing the words "F#" than Gb

      I know the chord name or even the note name will change depending on what key you're in. Nobody would say that Ab is the 3rd of Emajor because you go up the scale alphabetically and you don't want two A's (Ab and A natural)...

     that's right

      Maybe I'm wrong, but it seems to me the names of key signatures themselves, are kind of set in stone for the most part

     only when the choice is obvious

      Like, if I played you a song in Bb and asked you what key it was in... wouldn't you say Bb instead of A#?

     that's an extremely obvious case. Bb only has 2 flats where as the key of A# major would have 10 sharps. spelled out would be A#, B#, C double sharp, D#, E#, F double sharp, G double sharp

      Or is that just me?
original_html: 3.15.18  3:06 am   3.14.18  9:02 pm awfully theoretical there, bill

html:
3.10.18  9:18 am   How far can I go in learning drums without actually needing to play on a kit? I know rhythms from other instruments and I practice polyrhythms and coordination (like playing multiple patterns simultaneously.. not specifically 4:3 or 3:2 and that stuff) by tapping my feet/drumming on my desk with pencils or whatever. Will any of this be helpful if I actually sit down behind a drum set?

     Is there anything I should/could be doing until I get a kit (probably an electric kit since I live in an apartment)? 

8.6.17  11:33 am6.16.17  12:13 pm
embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201708061133

8.6.17  11:33 am   Hi, so I REALLY wanna learn to play the drums. I play guitar and bass, so I'm already familiar with playing music and how rhythm works (all the note/rest values, ties, triplets, etc. I'm even comfortable playing syncopated lines, polyrhythms, different time signatures and all that stuff) But when I actually try to sit down at a set and play around, I sound awful.. Do you think its mostly about building up muscle memory, just getting used to the technique and feeling of the drums? Another roadblock is that I don't own a kit (I live in an old apartment building, with VERY thin walls), so I practice either by tapping my feet while tapping on stuff with my hands, or by "air drumming". I really only get to play on an actual kit once a week or so at most (when I go over to a friends house for band practice). Any tips or advice???

     you can probably get pads that use a kick pedal, and you'll also need some regular drum pads, and then get like 3 or 4 snare stands, make sure they can go up high (so you can simulate the position of a high hat) and get a drum throne. and sticks of course. mentally, you can do a lot just in your mind, and simple tapping, when it comes to pattern practicing and independence, etc. You can actually even practice patterns with just the slightest twitch of your arm and leg muscles, and you will be able to simulate hand and foot patterns, and give your mind the necessary practice for integrating hand and foot patterns. But another important piece is the physical mechanics of the sticks and pedal, which you'll need to do on pads


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201706161213

6.16.17  12:13 pm   do you think it is possible to learn how to play a drum kit with little to no access to one? I've been a percussionist for years (marching band snare, djembe in church, etc.) but can't drum on an actual drum where i live. i desperately want to expand my abilities so I can just sit down at a set and play without feeling totally lost. i know i need a lot more limb independence and just straight up muscle memory to do that.... do you think it's possible to develop those any other way?

     you can probably get pads that use a kick pedal, and you'll also need some regular drum pads, and then get like 3 or 4 snare stands, make sure they can go up high (so you can simulate the position of a high hat) and get a drum throne. and sticks which you surely already have. or if you've got a lot more money, you could get an electronic drum kit. you already have stick technique, but getting a kick pedal and some way to play a pad with it will be helpful because learning to use a kick pedal is it's own thing, just like learning to use the sticks
original_html:

     you can probably get pads that use a kick pedal, and you'll also need some regular drum pads, and then get like 3 or 4 snare stands, make sure they can go up high (so you can simulate the position of a high hat) and get a drum throne. and sticks of course. mentally, you can do a lot just in your mind, and simple tapping, when it comes to pattern practicing and independence, etc. You can actually even practice patterns with just the slightest twitch of your arm and leg muscles, and you will be able to simulate hand and foot patterns, and give your mind the necessary practice for integrating hand and foot patterns. But another important piece is the physical mechanics of the sticks and pedal, which you'll need to do on pads

html:
3.9.18  10:56 pm   3.8.18  8:27 pm If you divide by a number less than one, it's a multiplication (in essence). Dividing 2 by 1/2 is 4, by 1/3 is 6, etc. In other words, the smaller the fraction, the higher the multiplication. Extrapolating, you can see that dividing by zero is (abstractly) the same as multiplying by infinity. So dividing by zero doesn't give you a real answer because infinity is an abstract concept (whereas numbers are abstract concepts that can have sort-of tangible real-life equivalents). Why don't you ever use capital letters?

when i do
embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201803082027

3.8.18  8:27 pm   what happens if you divide by 0?

     to divide something into zero pieces, you're going to need subtraction, not division
original_html:
3.9.18  10:56 pm   3.8.18  8:27 pm If you divide by a number less than one, it's a multiplication (in essence). Dividing 2 by 1/2 is 4, by 1/3 is 6, etc. In other words, the smaller the fraction, the higher the multiplication. Extrapolating, you can see that dividing by zero is (abstractly) the same as multiplying by infinity. So dividing by zero doesn't give you a real answer because infinity is an abstract concept (whereas numbers are abstract concepts that can have sort-of tangible real-life equivalents).
